abstract.p: 100th annual Christmas Bird Count records 120 species in Westchester County, New York (S)

block.p: The 100th annual Christmas Bird Count -- the 76th for the Bronx-Westchester area -- counted 120 species and 56,324 birds, reported Michael Bochnik, the compiler for local Audubon group.
It also showed that the crow count dropped sharply from last year, in part, Mr. Bochnik speculated, because many had been killed during this summer's outbreak of West Nile-like virus.
The 100th annual Christmas Bird Count -- the 76th for the Bronx-Westchester area -- counted 120 species and 56,324 birds, reported Michael Bochnik, the compiler for local Audubon group.
It also showed that the crow count dropped sharply from last year, in part, Mr. Bochnik speculated, because many had been killed during this summer's outbreak of West Nile-like virus.
The count was down this year to 1,349 from 3,547 last year.
The Christmas Day count drew about 70 bird counters on a morning when the temperature dipped to 23 degrees and the wind chill factor rose.
''One group started owling at 5 a.m.,'' Mr. Bochnik reported. ''The rest started at daybreak, about 7 a.m.''

A new bird -- the West Coast version of the dark-eyed junco, called a pink-sided junco, was found in Riverdale Park in the Bronx, probably a stray that had ''flown east instead of south,'' Mr. Bochnik said.
A Baltimore oriole, which would usually be in the South by now, was also spotted, as were two peregrine falcons, an endangered species, at Edith Read Sanctuary in Rye.
More ducks and geese were counted this year than in the past, most likely because the weather remained warmer for a longer period this fall and the waters stayed open, Mr. Bochnik said.
